{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3567644,"name":"iRobot_","username":"iRobot1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/e79b87/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T01:11:21.801Z","cooked":"

Hi All,

The previous robot design used a cancoder as a remote sensor on an arm that was controlled with motion magic. We determined setpoints using the absolute position on the cancoder with no issues.

The new robot design has the remote cancoder on a different gear ratio (cancoder spins faster than the mechanism). To get “360” rotation, we would now need to use the remote cancoder’s relative position OR the motors internal encoder. I think I prefer the remote cancoder due to having the absolute position to find the “offset” at the beginning of each match.

Ok, that being said. I think I took it for granted in the past. How does motion magic know to read the remote cancoder’s absolute position value rather than the relative position? Is there a way to use the remote cancoder’s relative position instead?

I think that we may need to pivot to a different strategy - perhaps leveraging the sensorToMechanismRatio? Not really sure how to use the cancoder’s relative position or if this is completely abstracted away and I don’t need to think about it. Looking for some advice on how to approach this issue.

Thanks in advance!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-03-25T01:11:21.801Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":71.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":496822,"topic_slug":"ctre-and-remote-sensors","display_username":"iRobot_","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22720,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/ctre-and-remote-sensors/496822/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3567680,"name":"Caleb Herring","username":"bobsfriend12","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bobsfriend12/{size}/242284_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T01:41:46.487Z","cooked":"

You can use a remote CANCoder like this:

TalonFXConfiguration config = new TalonFXConfiguration();
config.Feedback.withRemoteCANcoder(new CANcoder(0));
motor.getConfigurator().apply(config);

After you do this all of the other methods regarding the encoder will be using the cancoder, not the built in encoder.

If you’re not putting the CANCoder directly on the mechanism, then I don’t see why you wouldn’t just use the built in encoder. Putting the encoder directly on the mechanism means you could use it as an absolute encoder, meaning you wouldn’t need to set the zero.

If you’re set on having it behind a gear ratio, then there not much reason to use a CANCoder over the built-in encoder unless you’re worried about the encoder resolution.

If you do end up having it behind a gear ratio, then yes or can use the senorToMechanismRatio, or you can just leave it and have your setpoints be really weird numbers.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-03-25T01:41:46.487Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":69,"readers_count":68,"score":43.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":496822,"topic_slug":"ctre-and-remote-sensors","display_username":"Caleb Herring","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70725,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2338 Programming Captain"},"post_url":"/t/ctre-and-remote-sensors/496822/2","custom_user_title":"2338 Programming Captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3567708,"name":"iRobot_","username":"iRobot1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/e79b87/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T02:14:28.862Z","cooked":"

Thanks for the reply!

We have used the remote cancoder for some time now, so the issue is not on how to use it. The issue I am having is understanding how everything is happening “under the hood.”

I can specify a sensorToMechanism ratio and I can request “number of mechanism rotations.” Does this request automatically use the relative cancoder rotations if I request more than one turn? I assume it must.

If you’re not putting the CANCoder directly on the mechanism, then I don’t see why you wouldn’t just use the built in encoder. Putting the encoder directly on the mechanism means you could use it as an absolute encoder, meaning you wouldn’t need to set the zero.

I should still be able to utilize the absolute reading of the cancoder to ensure my relative position is in sync with the absolute position. Which would be useful to ensure that my mechanism doesn’t need to be initialized in the same state each time
